results.title: Les Sesterain Ou le Miroir 2000: Episode 13
results.brief_description:
The first section of Le Miroir 2000 is inaugurated as Pierre and Marie’s wedding is celebrated. The Flandin family is also in high spirit as Robert integrated the French National Team.

Credits: Producer, Pierre Long ; director, Francois Villiers ; writers, Andre Maheux, Francois Villiers ; photography, Paul Soulignac, Henri Raichi ; music, Francois de Roubaix.
Cast: Etienne Bierry, Jean-Claude Dauphin, Marie-Christine Barrault, Georges Claisse, Yves Lefebvre, Christian Alers, Marthe Villalonga, Marie-Helene Breillat.

results.title: Les Sesterain Ou le Miroir 2000: Episode 12
results.brief_description:
Antoine tenders his resignation from the Council under what he perceives the pressure from the villagers. Pierre and Antoine negotiate the truce, until the news arrives from Paris that Marie is pregnant.

Credits: Producer, Pierre Long ; director, Francois Villiers ; writers, Andre Maheux, Francois Villiers ; photography, Paul Soulignac, Henri Raichi ; music, Francois de Roubaix.
Cast: Etienne Bierry, Jean-Claude Dauphin, Marie-Christine Barrault, Georges Claisse, Yves Lefebvre, Christian Alers, Marthe Villalonga, Marie-Helene Breillat.

results.title: Les Sesterain Ou le Miroir 2000: Episode 11
results.brief_description:
Pierre and Marie runaway and attempt to cross the border to Italy. At the village Council, some realise that the new development of Le Miroir 2000 may not benefit their small businesses after all.

Credits: Producer, Pierre Long ; director, Francois Villiers ; writers, Andre Maheux, Francois Villiers ; photography, Paul Soulignac, Henri Raichi ; music, Francois de Roubaix.
Cast: Etienne Bierry, Jean-Claude Dauphin, Marie-Christine Barrault, Georges Claisse, Yves Lefebvre, Christian Alers, Marthe Villalonga, Marie-Helene Breillat.

results.title: Les Sesterain Ou le Miroir 2000: Episode 10
results.brief_description:
Following Francois’ death, Martine leaves Le Miroir for Paris. Lauzon is feeling the reprobation of all the village and is more and more isolated. When Pierre and Marie announce their intention to get married, Antoine disapproves strongly.

Credits: Producer, Pierre Long ; director, Francois Villiers ; writers, Andre Maheux, Francois Villiers ; photography, Paul Soulignac, Henri Raichi ; music, Francois de Roubaix.
Cast: Etienne Bierry, Jean-Claude Dauphin, Marie-Christine Barrault, Georges Claisse, Yves Lefebvre, Christian Alers, Marthe Villalonga, Marie-Helene Breillat.

results.title: Les Sesterain Ou le Miroir 2000: Episode 1
results.brief_description:
The series follows two years in the life of village of Le Miroir and its residents as they go through the transformation of their quiet Alpine village into a modern skiing resort, Le Miroir 2000. The main protagonist is Antoine Sesterain, the mayor of the village and farmer. Antoine is a widower with three sons, all deeply attached to the mountains: Henri, a resort manager, Francois, a skiing instructor engaged to Martine and Pierre, a restless student. Pierre is causing havoc at the boarding school he attends in the valley and where his uncle, Abbe Bonnevie teaches. Following a prank, Pierre is denied permission to leave the school to attend his brother Henri’s wedding. During the wedding, Lauzon, a local saw-mill owner approaches Antoine with the idea of turning Le Miroir into a skiing resort. Set in the mid-1960s, ‘Les Sesterain’ is a realistic rendition of the changes many mountain villages had to go through as France sought to exploit the ‘white gold’ and the rising interest in winter sports.

Credits: Producer, Pierre Long ; director, Francois Villiers ; writers, Andre Maheux, Francois Villiers ; photography, Paul Soulignac, Henri Raichi ; music, Francois de Roubaix.
Cast: Etienne Bierry, Jean-Claude Dauphin, Marie-Christine Barrault, Georges Claisse, Yves Lefebvre, Christian Alers, Marthe Villalonga.

results.title: Les Seins de Glace = Icy Breasts
results.creator_credit: Alain Delon, Raymond Danon and Georges Lautner
results.brief_description:
Francois Rollin, a TV writer, meets a lonely woman on the beach and pushes his way into her life. Peggy lives alone in a grand mansion with a groundkeeper cum spy. Rilsen, a lawyer, who is secretely in love with Peggy, is trying his best to push Rollin away from Peggy. But to no avail. The mysteries, the silences and the strange men surrounding Peggy only contribute to tease the TV writer’s curiosity. As Rollin delves further into Peggy’s past, he discovers that she has killed every man who has ever gotten close to her.

Credits: Producers, Raymond Danon, Alain Delon ; director, Georges Lautner ; writer, Georges Lautner ; photography, Maurice Fellous ; music, Philippe Sarde ; second assistant director, Robin Davis.
Cast: Mireille Darc, Alain Delon, Claude Brasseur, Nicoletta Machiavelli, Andre Falcon.

results.title: Les Revoltes de Lomanach = the Rebels of Lomanach
results.brief_description:
In Vendee (western France) in 1799, Barnaud invades the estate of Lomanach with a group of Republican soldiers. Before the Revolution Barnaud used to be the estate manager of Lomanach. Monique, daughter of the owner, attempts to seduce Barnaud in order to kill him and save the estate. ‘Les Revoltes de Lomanach’ was France’s first widescreen feature presentation. This version is presented in standard screen ratio 3:4.

Credits: Producer, Francois Chavanne ; director, Richard Pottier ; writer, Jacques Sigurd, Leo Joannon ; photography, Jean Leherissey ; music, Georges van Parys ; assistant director, Claude Sautet ; costumes, Rosine Delamare.
Cast: Amedeo Nazzari, Dany Robin, Michel Vitold, Carla Del Poggio, Jacques Castelot, Jean Debucourt, Robert Dalban.

results.title: Les Premiers Empires
results.brief_description:
Episode 5 of Series “Il Etait Une Fois L’homme” (= “Once Upon a Time Man”).
Hammourabi, king of Babylon writes the first legal code. In this world made of rival cities, visionary rulers push and battle to built vast empires. This episode follows Darius, king of Persia and his many battles to expand his empire eastward to encompass Greece and Athens. It also recounts the formidable epic of Alexander the Great who succeeded in uniting Greece and Persia under his command.

Credits: Director, writer, Albert Barille ; photography, Jean-Louis Karcher ; art direction, Philippe Landrot, Rene Borg ; graphic research, Jean Barbaud.
Cast: Roger Carel, Francine Laine, Pierre Trabaud, Henri Djanik [original French narration].

results.title: Les Portes de la Nuit = Gates of the Night
results.creator_credit: Pierre Laurent, Raymond Borderie and Marcel Carne
results.brief_description:
Paris during the winter after the Liberation. Diego meets up with his friend Raymond Lecuyer. A tramp pretending to be Destiny predicts Diego will meet the most beautiful girl in the world. The same evening, Diego meets Malou. Malou is the daughter of a businessman who does not disguise his sympathy for the now defunct Vichy regime. Diego soon discovers that Malou’s brother, Guy, was the one who denounced Raymond to the Gestapo. Carne and Prevert paint a realistic portrait of the social landscape of France immediately after the Liberation, with its war victims, resistants, black-marketeers and Vichy nostalgics. For ‘Les portes de la nuit’ Alexandre Trauner re-created in studio the metro station Barbes-Rochechouart and several facades of houses along the canal St Martin.

Credits: Producers, Raymond Borderie, Pierre Laurent ; director, Marcel Carne ; writer, Jacques Prevert ; photography, Philippe Agostini ; music, Joseph Kosma ; art direction, Alexandre Trauner ; stills photographer, Raymond Voinquel.
Cast: Pierre Brasseur, Serge Reggiani, Yves Montand, Nathalie Nattier, Saturnin Fabre, Raymond Bussieres, Jean Vilar, Sylvia Bataille, Jane Marken, Dany Robin, Fabien Loris, Mady Berry, Julien Carette.

results.title: Les Parents Terribles
results.creator_credit: Francis Cosne, Alexandre Mnouchkine and Jean Cocteau
results.brief_description:
When the son of a middle-class Parisian family announces his love for a young woman, neither he nor his domineering mother, who cannot accept his adulthood, know that the girl is the mistress of his father. Reference: Bloomsbury Film Guide.

Credits: Producers, Alexandre Mnouchkine, Francis Cosne ; writer, director, Jean Cocteau ; photography, Michel Kelber ; music, Georges Auric.
Cast: Jean Marais, Josette Day, Yvonne de Bray, Marcel Andre, Gabrielle Dorziat.
